title: Georgia House - Day 39 (2026-03-29)
summary:
Overview:
The Georgia House session on 2026-03-29 (legislative day 39) featured a diverse array of legislative activities, from the introduction of several bills to notable speeches and procedural matters.

Key Actions:
- **HB 826**: Not mentioned in the transcript provided.
- **SB 156**: Not mentioned in the transcript provided.
- **SB 260**: Not mentioned in the transcript provided.
- **SB 59**: Not mentioned in the transcript provided.
- **SB 213**: Not mentioned in the transcript provided.

Bills Introduced (First Reading):
The transcript does not mention any bills being introduced for first reading.

Notable Moments:
- The session opened with a scripture reading and prayer led by Pastor David McKinley, who delivered a thought-provoking sermon on the significance of the resurrection of Jesus Christ.
- The Speaker received a special "Amen" hat from Pastor McKinley, which provided a lighthearted moment.
- Pastor McKinley shared personal anecdotes and reflections on his ministry, highlighting the challenges and privileges he has faced over the years.

Votes:
The transcript does not mention any recorded votes.

Attendance:
The session began with a quorum call, during which members were instructed to vote green to signify their presence.

Adjournment:
The transcript does not provide information on the adjournment of the session or the date of the next scheduled session.

All members of the House will please report to their assigned seats. All members of the House of Representatives will please report to their seats. Oracle Ring the Bell. We are about to have the morning roll call. We are about to have the morning roll call. All members present will please vote green to signify their presence in the chamber and the clerk will unlock the machines. I'm not telling you. If all members now voted, the clerk will lock the machines. Doorkeepers will please close the doors and keep them closed. We will begin our day, legislative day 39 with scripture, reading and prayer by the chaplain, after which we will pledge allegiance to the flag of our country. Our chaplain this morning will be introduced by the gentleman from the 123rd House District Chairman Mark Newton. It is a joy and privilege to introduce my friend and my pastor, David McKinley. David has this rare ability to convert complex biblical doctrine into every day language. Language that can both challenge and motivate change. He is the senior pastor at our church, Warren Baptist Church, and Augusta, leading a ministry team reaching out to thousands of families in our area every week. We are glad that he and his wife Connie, who I hope is watching, are serving with us these past 13 years. Previously David, pastor at Merritt Island and Boko Raton, Florida, but I have heard from a hint that he has grown to love a little island off the Georgia coast that the speakers fond of and Mayor Don Hogan is fond of, St. Simon's Island. He is also the author of two books, the latest of which is The Life You Were Born To Give. David and Connie are blessed with two children and six grandchildren. Finally, Pastor David reminded us that God calls him to comfortably afflicted and to afflict the comfortable. This past year has certainly seen challenges in how we comfort others in time of loss, loss of jobs, loss of fellowship, even loss of life. David and the team have done a wonderful job reaching out in new and caring ways in a challenging year. He is also never strayed from the second part that I mentioned of afflicting the comfortable of challenging each of us not to be satisfied with the status quo, but for each of us not just on Sunday to reach out to others regardless of any situational differences to motivate us to bring unity and make a positive difference in the lives, families, and communities around us. I trust you will appreciate this as well as we hear this morning from my friend Dr. David McKinley. Thank you, sir. Greetings and blessings to each of you today. And thank you so much, Mr. Speaker. And to each of you representatives from across the breath of the life of Georgia and my dear friend Mark Newton, Dr. Newton, who is a congressman who is a physician who has all sorts of things that he does and I'm so thankful for that. And I do bring you greetings today from the Garden City of Augusta, Georgia, where we are seven days away from the great tradition of the masters, the 85th edition of the masters. And I believe this week that you all have received some hats that are allowing you to participate in that. I brought one more of those that I want to present to the speaker this morning. And it's kind of one of my favorites. It's the Amen hat. And so Mr. Speaker, I want you to be in my corner today and get an Amen before I even begin. Okay, so there we go. Thank you. So very much. I appreciate that. So we have the Amen corner hat up here today. Now I realize that as I come before you this morning that I am on your turf and that I want to both honor your time and your attentiveness. But in a unique scheduling sequence, we are also in a place where you are on my turf. I am not a lobbyist or a legislator. I am a pastor and a teacher. Throughout my life and throughout my ministry, I have tried to be faithful to the calling that really I sensed when I was 15 years of age, 15 years old that I had a sense of coming and doing what I'm doing today. Now obviously a lot of time has passed since I was 15. I am now in that category of life where I'm often asked, senior, and I always respond, no, I just turned 40, but I've had a really hard life. And that's what I always try to say to help people to understand. When I was 15 years of age, I never could have imagined the challenges, the struggles, the hardships, the tragedies that I would face in years of ministry. I will return home this week to officiate in a funeral service for the loss of a husband and a father, a former veteran whose wife, 39 years of age, is left with three children. As you know, this is so much a part of life that we walk through the struggles. I also could have never estimated, and I have often underestimated the enormity and the regularity of the conflicts and challenges and changes that I would face over these last four decades. And I know that you are not in any way unaccustomed to personally dealing with conflicts and challenges in your life. I think the greatest leadership maxim I've ever learned is this. I cannot make everybody happy, but I can make everybody mad. And I think you understand that as well, right? I also never dreamed of the privileges and the platforms that would be extended to me, one of which is standing in front of you today. But as I'm here in my life, just as in your life, a lot of different things have shaped the growth, the development, the experience of my life. And one of those happened really after I graduated from college, and while I was working on my master's in seminary, I threw a paper out. 286 copies of the commercial appeal newspaper from Memphis, Tennessee every day of my life for seven days a week for over three years. And you know something that was true of that experience was that never on one occasion did I ever write the news and never did I print the paper. All that I did was delivered it. And as I come before you today, that is the spirit in which I come. I simply want to stand in this holy week here between Palm Sunday and Good Friday and Easter and to deliver to you what I believe to be the most important message in all the world. In 1 Corinthians 15, verse 3, the Apostle Paul said, for I delivered to you as the first importance what I also received that Christ died for our sins and accordance with the scriptures that he was buried and that he was raised on the third day and accordance with the scriptures. And then he appeared to Peter and then to the 12 and then to over 500 eyewitnesses. Here in this one text we have the totality and the simplicity of the message that is known as the gospel. The word gospel means good news. And the good news is that God sent his son Christ to die for our sins because we are a lot of faulted people and we need forgiveness. That Christ was buried in order that he might taste death and then that he rose again on the third day to give healing and hope to all who would look to him and that that testimony of the resurrection was not simply something that was passed but something that would be carried on through over 500 witnesses who were willing to risk their lives for the reality of this message. And so the whole of the message of the Christian faith has built on the reality of the resurrection of Jesus Christ. It was the Anglican theologian John Stott who said it well when he said Christianity is in its very essence, a resurrection religion. The concept of resurrection lies at its heart. If you remove it, Christianity is destroyed. And he's exactly right. Paul in this same chapter went on to play his own skeptic when he wrote on down in verse 13, for if there is no resurrection from the dead, then our preaching is in vain. Your faith is futile. And even we, that is the disciples, are found to be misrepresenting God because we testified that Jesus rose from the dead. And if Christ is not raised, your faith is futile, you're still in your sins and those who have fallen asleep in Christ have perished. And if in Christ we have hope in this life only, we are of all people to be most pitted. Think about what he just said there. He said, if Christ is not alive, then all preaching is pointless. I don't know about you, but I've heard some pointless preaching in my time. Can I get an amen on that one at least? Yeah, there's plenty of pointless preaching, but what I'm here to tell you today is it's not an issue of pointless preaching. He essentially Paul is saying if Christ isn't risen, there is no good news because there is no news. And while some men may live a lie, few are willing to die for a lie and the disciples were willing to die for the truth of the resurrection. He says faith is futile, even foolish. We talk a lot in our world today about believing, but the question is not just do you believe? What do you believe? Faith isn't just a subjective thing, it's an objective thing. There must be a foundation of our faith. And then he says, if this is true, then the disciples are deceivers. They weren't just good men who didn't know better. They were bad men who willingly and knowingly deceived. He even used the courtroom scene. He said, we miss represent through our testimony. He was talking about perjury. And if Christ is not alive, then death is final and the future is fearful. The only universal truth if Christ does not live is death. And then he says that the very end, Christ's followers are pitiful people. That sounds more like late night with Bill Mar than it does a biblical passage. Because if there is no Easter, then there is no hope. I love what Timothy Keller said when he said, if Jesus rose from the dead, then you have to accept all that he said. If he didn't rise from the dead, then why worry about anything that he said? The issue on which everything hangs is not whether or not you like his teaching, but whether or not he rose from the dead. And I stand before you to share testimony today that my hope is not in the Christian faith tradition, but it stands on the firm foundation of the resurrection of Jesus Christ. Because I believe this to be the message of hope and the message of healing because it is a message of power. Jesus didn't just come to show us how to live a good life. He came to give us power, to give us a new life. And I would just simply say and be so bold as to suggest to you today that the greatest need in our world today is not for more information or inspiration, not more moral teaching or psychological understanding, and not even greater economics or education, though every one of these has their place. The greatest need that we have right now in our world is for power. And I believe that that power is found in the name of Jesus Christ and His resurrection. I close with this, SM Lock Ridge, an African-American pastor who for 40 years shepherded the Calvary Baptist Church in San Diego, California, who was known for his alignment and allegiance through the civil rights era and hosted Dr. Martin Luther King in his church. I may be naive, but I think there are plenty of people in this room just as there are in every congregation that I stand in front of, who today need help and healing and hope. And I pray that in the face of all of the issues that divide us and the doubts that surround us and the discouragement that weighs on us and the despair and the defeat that inevitably causes us to look at the reality of death that threatens us, that you will take some time this week to read and to consider the witness in the testimony of Paul in 1 Corinthians chapter 15. recognizes Chairman Lynn Smith and members of the Caluina County delegation along with their neighbors in that part of West Georgia for a morning order. Good morning everyone and thank you for your awareness by standing like you are today for what happened to our county last Friday morning. We truly had not yet absorbed what's happened to our county all of us have been out in it working doing our part. We have some information up here on the board for our local governments for you to make contributions if you want to. But there is a story to tell here all of us were out in our communities experiencing what the people we know and love so well were dealing with. But please indulge us for a moment as we share this story with you because it's worth telling. My county and the district we represent all of us here has been wiped out in so many places by midnight tornado and EF4. 170 miles per hour and I'll say that five more times 170,000 miles per hour. Yeah that's incomprehensible. It roared with very little warning, pale male through our homes and lives. The dawn brought us to silent witness of what had happened. The day saw scrambling like ants in an ant bed that had just been kicked open as we moved about trying to comprehend. Most of us were able to do a flyover of the area to see what had happened. This flyover gave us a sense of destruction. Six miles of sustained winds on our land. Wide in places, fourth of miles is the smallest area that was hit. This is still incomprehensible for all of us here today. But when we got back home to our homes and when we went out to see what we could do to help, some had chain saws, some were bringing water, we were all trying to do it. But this is what we saw later, the walkabout. Actually as we stumbled about, it gave us a bone chilling wake up call to the 3D demolishing of our homes, trees, lives, chaos, chaos. But then as if a movie producer snapped the scene marker, a symphonic energy emerged. There were checking for survivors, trees were moved off roads and houses. And when I tell you checking for survivors, that is really true. You had to move things out of the way and you were trying to find out where they home that morning. It was a story that we knew would never end. But the utility trucks came in from everywhere, volunteer groups of all kinds materialized and good things began to happen. As if our lives were now being guided by an airstrip. Chaos was being reshaped and reformed. We have such a long way to go. How do you replace a high school that has anchored our lives for over 70 years? I taught there during desegregation, the history and the goodwill this high school has for our community still exists, but there will not be any structure for almost two years because it was demolished. How do you replace trees that are over 100 years old? How do you regain the store combs, both in the wealthy areas of our area and in the poorest areas of our area? How do you cope? How do you survive? How do you thrive? Well, I can tell you, as we are witnessing it now, the talent and creativity that has long defined noon and in cowita is being put to good use, guiding our energies into a 21st century marvel. We know that is our goal. There is no woe in us with God is our strength. This is from Corinthians. With God is our strength and our guiding light, we can overcome and survive our hardships. But it is with your compassion that you are showing today. It is the compassion of so many leaders in our state. We have schools, bedwacking, Jema. We are really living almost as if we have just been a bomb that area. But thank you. We don't have all the information to tell you now because so many have already spoken to us about helping us. Look at our delegation here today. We have Randy Knicks here with the story to tell us about Howard County. Coming from Howard County and Cowita County. What is still incomprehensible to me to all of us though is that no one died. I know. Y'all. But it wasn't for lack of that storm trying. We can all give you a tale. There was one man who heard the siren and was trying to get to his family in time to help them and he died of a heart attack on the way. It is not counter-deserved to this storm. But it is an example of how much compassion and wherewithal that we as people have when we pull together. We are a faith-based state. That is so obvious. I stood with our ministers. I stood with the principal of the high school that was no more. And I said, you've just been through COVID. I said, you know, at least you haven't trained to do virtual learning. I said, but what about the Asprey to Core? What about the campus? What about the next year? But those are things we don't answer. I think Chairman Smith said it very well. It's hard not to get emotional about it. We're all very tired. It was a very long weekend. We have an unbelievable support.
